awd_titl_txt: REU Site: BIGDatA - Big Data Analytics for Cyber-physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The funding renews a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at New Mexico State University. Undergraduate students will participate in summer research projects guided by faculty research mentors using state-of-the-art labs and facilities.  Cyber-physical systems are real-world systems, such as automotive systems, medical systems, smart homes, and manufacturing systems, that have computer algorithms and software monitoring and controlling them. These systems generate large amounts data that is complex and diverse. Big data analytics are essential to effectively use, protect, and enhance most cyber-physical systems. The REU students will participate in a variety of activities including team-based research projects, training workshops, field trips, conference participation, and other professional development opportunities that will prepare them for research in the timely and important field of big data for cyber-physical systems and prepare them for future careers as computing professionals.

The project is led by researchers currently exploring aspects of big data and cyber-physical systems.  The research explores big data analytics for cyber-physical systems in three intertwined dimensions: systems and architectures, models and algorithms, and visualization.  The research spans four application areas including unmanned systems, smart grids, wireless sensor networks, and smart homes. The goals of the project include: motivating and solidifying students’ interest in computer science and in big data analytics and security for cyber-physical systems; providing students with problem solving and research skills;  equipping students with knowledge of data management and data analytics techniques;  enhancing self-confidence and self-efficacy of the student participants; equipping students with professional knowledge and skills including communication, teamwork, and ethics; and broadening participation in computing and the computing workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The award has supported 30 participants in total during three 10-week summer programs (2021, 2022, 2023), where each cohort has 10 participants. We summarize our outcomes in what follows.


Intellectual Merits. 
The participants have gained a broad understanding of big data analytics for cyber-physical systems (CPS) by working on different research projects. The students are trained on conducting research, writing critical research articles, making effective presentations, and applying for graduate schools and fellowships through different workshops. 
(1) Participant publications and presentations. The REU participants who were supported by this award have published six research papers in conference proceedings and workshops. Participants presented eight posters at different conferences including Emerging Researchers National (ERN) conference, Great Minds in STEM conference, and local regional conferences. Two undergraduate students (Eddy J. Figueroa Picon and Juan Torres) won 2nd and 3rd place respectively in the undergraduate poster presentation at ERN 2024. 
(2) Participants going to graduates schools. Among the 30 participants, 20 have obtained their bachelor's degree and 13 of them either have started their graduate studies or are going to start them in Fall 2024.

Broader Impacts.
Our REU Site has attracted the interest of many students. We received 58, 40, and 115 applications in the three years, respectively, and accepted 30 in total (14%). All selected participants meet the application requirements and have good academic preparation for the summer research. The participants of our REU site have shown diversity in their ethnicity and gender. We use the most recent CRA Taulbee Survey (2022-2023) as national norm for comparison. Among the 30 participants in our REU site, 11 are female. This ratio (36.7%) is much higher than the national norm (22.7%). The 30 participants are from different ethnicity and race groups: 12 Hispanics, 7 Caucasians, 6 Asians, 3 African Americans, and 2 others (multi-racial). The participant ratios of Hispanics participants and African American participants (40% and 10%) are 2X higher than the national norm (9.8% and 4.1%). These statistics show that our REU site has been very successful in recruiting traditionally underrepresented minority students. In particular, we have focused on Hispanic students because NMSU is a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI). 

Other Impacts.
The REU Site has been instrumental in creating a campus-wide interest on data analytics at NMSU; new collaborations among mentors have emerged, leading to submissions of joint proposals. 


Last Modified: 06/17/2024
Modified by: Huiping Cao
